name: United States of America
description: US employment law follows the at-will doctrine with federal and state regulations

employmentType.rule: At-will employment is the default. Either party may terminate employment at any time for any lawful reason without notice.
employmentType.exceptions: Contracts may establish fixed terms. Some states have additional protections.

minimumWage.rule: Federal minimum wage is $7.25 per hour under the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA).
minimumWage.exceptions: States and cities may set higher minimum wages. Tipped employees have a lower base rate of $2.13/hour with tip credit.

overtime.rule: Non-exempt employees must receive 1.5x regular pay rate for hours worked over 40 per workweek.
overtime.exceptions: Exempt employees (executive, administrative, professional, outside sales) are not entitled to overtime.

paidTimeOff.rule: No federal requirement for paid vacation, sick leave, or holidays for private employers.
paidTimeOff.exceptions: Some states (California, New York) mandate paid sick leave. FMLA provides 12 weeks unpaid leave for qualifying reasons.

workingHours.rule: No federal limit on hours worked per week for employees 16 years and older.
workingHours.exceptions: Certain industries (transportation, healthcare) have specific rest requirements.

terminationNotice.rule: No federal requirement for advance notice of termination for individual employees.
terminationNotice.exceptions: WARN Act requires 60 days notice for mass layoffs of 100+ employees. Contracts may specify notice periods.

antiDiscrimination.rule: Title VII prohibits discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, and national origin. ADA protects disability. ADEA protects age 40+.
antiDiscrimination.exceptions: Applies to employers with 15+ employees (20+ for ADEA).

nonCompete.rule: Non-compete agreements are generally enforceable if reasonable in scope, duration, and geography.
nonCompete.exceptions: California bans most non-compete agreements. FTC has proposed nationwide restrictions.

benefits.rule: Employers with 50+ FTEs must offer affordable health insurance or face penalties under the ACA.
benefits.exceptions: Small employers are exempt. COBRA continuation applies to employers with 20+ employees.

dataPrivacy.rule: No comprehensive federal employee data privacy law. Employers must safeguard sensitive personal information.
dataPrivacy.exceptions: CCPA/CPRA in California provides employee data rights. HIPAA applies to health information.
